body: no, `[[` is a bash invention, and `[` is defined by posix, so any shell implements it

interesting PR. i assume MSG_FASTOPEN uses the same value across all archs, so imo it would be better to have

```
#ifndef MSG_FASTOPEN
#define MSG_FASTOPEN 0x20000000
#endif
```

and remove the conditional compilation.
that way we produce a .so that works the same way on machines with old and new kernels

Since we don't actually call sendto(FASTOPEN) on old kernels that do not support it, but issuing connect, this seems to be a good idea. I will try to test it then write back to you. Thanks for suggestion.

can you add `__OpenBSD__` to that list as well so we can close #83 as well
please see also the other comments in that issue (for example it's sufficient to check for s6_addr16 only) also about where to put the block
'tis better to use (void) write(...) here, since we dont want error message output from here.

what you're doing here is not just ugly, it's outright wrong. the functions we're dealing with have all different prototypes so we would need the right function pointer type for every single function.
thankfully according to the standard, all pointers can be cast to void* legally (and only to void*).

you're polishing a turd. what i want to say is that this is dead code, that only gets activated if a user explicitly compiles the code with -DDEBUG (there's not even a configure switch for that).
apart from that the change you propose is utterly verbose since you not just duplicate the variadic code, you even change the toplevel macro name so all calling sites need to be touched!

this change can open a new can of worms, since the build will fail on every platform where the function prototype is only even cosmetically different from what the libc headers declare.
that means that this change will eventually break the build on musl libc, uclibc, newlib, freebsd, etc and does not even fix a warning.

The original source failed to compile due to `feature_tests.h`:
```c
...
#elif (_XOPEN_SOURCE - 0 = 600) || (_POSIX_C_SOURCE - 0 = 200112L)
#define _XPG6

...

#if defined(_STDC_C99) && (defined(__XOPEN_OR_POSIX) && !defined(_XPG6)
#error "Compiler or option invalid for pre-UNIX 03 X/Open applications and pre-2001 POSIX applications"
```

The source is compiling using `-std=c99`, then this `#error` is triggered.

body: what's the point of separating this out ? i can't see it conditionally used later on
does using _GNU_SOURCE cause build failure on solaris ?

No, this is just to add `-D_GNU_SOURCE` to later check_compile calls.

Since the actual sources is compiled with `-D_GNU_SOURCE`, the test compiles should also define this; same reason for `C99_CFLAGS`.
If you consider this `check_compile` is unnecessary, it can be replaced with `OUR_CPPFLAGS="$OUR_CPPFLAGS -D_GNU_SOURCE`

body:
There are 2 options not recognized by Solaris ld `--no-as-needed` and `-soname=<name>`

`--no-as-needed` is not need for Solaris ld, since it is not have such bug to workaround by this option.

`-soname=<name>` could be replaced to `-h <name>`, and the later form is also accepted by GNU ld.

body: I have no other way but treats Solaris specially.
why 14 ?
why is release_all() necessary ?

`select_proxy()` just finds a proxy in `PLAY_STATE`,  and then tries to connect via this proxy. `release_all()` resets all proxies' state to `PLAY_STATE`
The changes have two purposes:
1. If all proxies failed, wait and retry, so we call `release_all()` before another select loop.
2. Fast fail, if all proxies failed, we don't wait too long. So I choose 14 loops sums up with 1.05 second
The original code is a bit confusing
1. In this if condition waits for an available proxy https://github.com/rofl0r/proxychains-ng/blob/master/src/core.c#L614-L619
2. While in this else block, https://github.com/rofl0r/proxychains-ng/blob/master/src/core.c#L619-L624  if all proxies have failed to connect in one loop, just `goto error`

I pushed another commit to have better error handling
where does the seemingly arbitrary number 14 come from ? is it some "lucky number" in china ?

The number 14  has no special meaning. As I said first loop waits 10ms, then each loop increases 10ms, 14 loops sums up with 1.05s. When all proxies are not available, what we can do is either retry or raise an error. Do you have some better suggestions?
well i thought a config variable would maybe be more suitable. but then it seems you're the only one using round robin mode anyway...
the added indentation here is wrong, it makes it look as if the statement belongs to the if(...) above
Fixed
`strncpy()` doesn't do what you think it does. use `snprintf(pbuf, sizeof pbuf, "%s", path)` instead

-# define PDEBUG(fmt, args...) PSTDERR("DEBUG:"fmt, ## args)

body: Hah! Good catch, that was unintentional... 3am coding...

strncpy() has 2 properties ppl aren't usually aware of
1) strncpy doesn't zero-terminate the resulting string if the strlen is >= buffer length
2) strncpy always zero-pads the entire buffer, means if the buffersize is 64K and the string is 5 bytes, it will write 64K characters

while 2) is just very ineffective, 1) can turn into an exploitable security issue

we don't need to actually run the binary (which is incompatible with cross-compilation).
if it compiles, it means pipe2 is supported.
Unfortunately, no. I initially tested `check_compile` on my system, due to C implicit function definition, it will silently pass the compile test! Let me see if `check_compile` itself can be fixed...
-Werror-implicit-function-declaration
